data.title: Western Cape dam levels dip slightly as winter approaches
data.meta_description: As of 20 May, the City continues to monitor water levels and advises residents to use water sparingly despise recording above average rain fall during the early winter rains.
data.text:
The catchment of the major dams that service the Western Cape, including the Cape Town systems of dams, have slightly dropped ahead of the winter season.

Also read: Western Cape dam levels: Promising, with necessary precautions

Compared to last week’s levels, each dam experienced a slight drop:

Cape Town is heavily dependent on surface water contained in six major dams, including the Wemmershoek, Voelvlei, Steenbras, Theewaterskloof and Berg River Dams.

Cape {town} Etc discount: Looking for things to do in the city, at half the price? Get exclusive offers here.

As of 20 May, the City continues to monitor water levels and advises residents to use water sparingly despite recording above average rain fall during the early winter rains.

Minor dams experienced a 0.78% drop compared to last week:

Furthermore, Cape Town’s drinking water quality compliance has steadily averaged around 99%, coming in at 99.20% in April. For more information on the City’s weekly water dashboard, visit this link.

Western Cape dam levels remain high well into summer season
